Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Applied Research in Modeling and Data-Enabled Science (ARCHIMEDES) Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU program couples data-enabled science with mathematical modeling. The goal is to attract and retain students in STEM fields and to introduce them to this novel and exciting area of mathematical research. The objectives of the program are: to introduce students to scientific computing to strengthen programming skills, to use mathematical models to solve real-world problems, to apply computational tools to research-level problems, and to analyze results using data and translate into a scientific context. In this way, this REU site will not only expose students to an upcoming, data-intensive science, but will also promote creation, development, and application of novel tools essential for addressing the challenges of this emerging field. This REU program will provide a rigorous and meaningful research experience in modeling and data-enabled sciences for undergraduate students in a team environment, improve the communication skills of future mathematical researchers, and recruit potential researchers in data-enabled sciences.

This REU project will support eight undergraduate students for nine weeks each summer as they learn and develop the mathematical and computational tools necessary for data-driven applications, and as they gain professional-level research experiences in preparation for careers in STEM fields. In the first week, students will participate in a computational "bootcamp" designed to develop fundamental computational skills, preparatory to doing research during the rest of their summer program. The students will then work intensely for the remaining eight weeks, in teams of four and with a faculty mentor, on projects with strong computational and modeling components. Students will actively participate in weekly workshops and presentations to practice and improve their communication skills. They will also produce a technical report and a poster, and present at a public research symposium at the end of the program. Recruitment efforts will target groups that have been underrepresented in the STEM fields, including women, African Americans, Hispanics, American Indians, Alaskan Natives, Pacific Islanders and persons with disabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Applied ResearCH In ModEling and Data-Enabled Science (ARCHIMEDES) REU Programat the University of California, Merced aimed to provide undergraduate students a professional level research experience to prepare them for STEM-related careers. In particular, the objectives of the program were to (i) introduce students to scientific computing to strengthen programming skills, (ii) use mathematical models to solve real-world problems, (iii) apply computational tools to research level problems, and (iv) analyze results using data and translate into scientific context. The research projects covered diverse topics in applied mathematics, including fluid dynamics, computational genomics, image processing, sensitivity analysis, inverse problems, and mathematical biology.  The projects were self-contained in that didactic training was provided to accommodate for the needs of students coming from different levels of education and experience. 


The first week of each summer program consisted of an orientation with all the undergraduate summer research program on campus.  A "computational bootcamp" provided initial training in the fundamentals of computational mathematics.  There was also a review of topics related to the research projects (such as calculus, linear algebra, and differential equations) at the beginning of each summer program.  The weekly activities consisted of group meetings with the faculty mentors, professional development workshops, and progress report presentations at the end of each week.  Visits to the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory were arranged, where students toured the computing facilities and heard research talks by  lab scientists.  The summer REU program culminated with the university-wide Annual Summer Research Symposium, where the students gave oral research presentations and presented research posters.  


A total of 25 undergraduate students participated, 13 of whom were women.  Students were recruited from all over the country, with most attending primarily undergraduate institutions.  About half continued on to graduate school in various fields (biomedical engineering, applied mathematics, pure mathematics, statistics, and biology), with three students receiving NSF Graduate Research Fellowships.  Others are pursuing careers in industry as software engineers, research assistants, risk analysts, and business analysts.
